column4: yo guys, i'm trying to change the security of a router, and i'm trying to access it to do so, but I am unable to find the router's IP adress, or the one I find simply isn't working [16:27] <thecpaptain> right now i'm operating in windows, as I am unable to access the LAN via Ubuntu
Wired or WiFi?
Do you have permission from landlord?
If so, the router's IP will more than likely be default route.  i.e.  192.168.1.1
Bring up the command prompt and issue command  ipconfig
what is the route  (Default GW)
take your browser to 10.0.1.1
What is make and model of router?
Some routers have an option to only accept connection from wired and/or from one particular IP
Refer to router manual for details.
Sounds like you are unable to connect to the router because of unknown passphrase or wep key (password).  Right?
Is that correct?
Then what is the problem?  What exactly do you need to accomplish?
- the original problem is that i'm unable to access the network using ubuntu
You can not duplicate the process the windows PC uses?  Tell it to show you the passphrase, (or what ever).  What type of security is it using?
If you're wondering what security the Router is using? I think its WPA2, but I'm guessing you're asking me to verify
Look at the connection configuration the Windows PC uses.
hm yeah I just did, its WPA2-Personal
SO that doesn't work for you on the Ubuntu machine?
hm, I haven't verified it to be the actual reason, but talking to people have lead it to seem the most likely
Does the network-manager come up and ask for passphrase?
i'm able to access other networks in Ubuntu, and it finds other networks and even the network i'm trying to access, it just keeps processing when i'm trying to access it
yes, and it automatically sets it to WPA2-personal
and even though I put the correct phrase, it doesn't allow me access
Ok then it is associating with the essid of the WiFi router? (But not acquirig IP info)?
Is that correct?
no idea, I don't know what that means hehe. How do I find out ?
iwconfig
ifconfig
so should i run iwconfig in windows ? or is it still ipconfig we're talking about ?
and should i do it in windows or Ubuntu ?
you there ?
On the Ubuntu PC, open a terminal, type  iwconfig  (and hit enter)  THen type ifconfig (and hit enter).
and then return, paste and give it to you, right ?
I need to know since its this comp that i need to reboot in Ubuntu in order to do it
that's why i'm so cautious before doing it ;)
I see.
should I go ahead and do it ?
First, verify the wpa passphrase on the MS Windows side.
Tell the MS Windows PC to show the passphrase.
aight, I'm positive i have the right one though
got it, its verified
Give it a shot.
aight, i'll log into the wonderful world of ubuntu and shall return to this shatroom shorty, brb
Ok, good luck
here be the results http://paste.ubuntu.com/680730/
You will need to compare and see if the essid is correct for the AP you are trying to connect to.
hm, firstly, what is an essid, and how do i do that ?
hm, firstly, what is an essid, and how do i do that ?
any ideas ?

essid is the network name that a Wireless Access Point uses.  The first step in accessing a Wireless Access Point is getting the Wireless Network Adapter to assign itself the same essid that the Wireless Access Point uses.
hm i see
If there is encryption, that must be negotiated first.
hm all right, so how do we find out whether the essids match ?
any ideas ?

Once the proper passphrase is entered and received by the Wireless Access Point, the PC's Wireless Network Adapter can associate using the same essid (name) as the Wireless Access Point.  Then the PCs Wireless Network Adapter asks for IP information from the Wireless Access Point's DHCP server.  If the DHCP server receives the request and sends back proper IP information, the Wireless Network Adapter on your PC will use that information to establis
to establish a connection
We can not make all that stuff work, only you can.
yeah I figured as much, but how do I go about doing it ?
I have given you all the information I have.
all right, if you don't have any further ideas then thank you for what you have so far provided :)
so you don't think the problem might be the WPA2 connection and Ubuntu ?
Yes I DO think the problem is with the WPA2 authentication.  More than likely, yes.
If y ou could turn off the encryption, that would do the trick.
But we can not do that for you.  Only you can.
and for that i need to access the router, hence the router's configuration challenge right ?
You need to know the make and model of the router. YOu probably also need  a wired connection to it, etc.
hmm
sudo iwconfig essid type-essid-here
the ESSID i want to change to is the one that iwconfig showed me as Nickname:"XXXXX" ?
There is one possibility and that is that network-manager is imporperly negotiating the wpa authentication.  In which case, you could switch to wicd.
sudo apt-get remove network-manager ; sudo apt-get install wicd
aight, should i try that before or after the Essid thingie ?
Yes
hm, the ssid seems to match the one in Network manager
i'll try the wicd
if i type the commands you showed me, will i not lose my internet connection before ubuntu is able to acquire the wicd ?
you there mate ?
Yes
if i type the commands you showed me, will I not lose network manager before its able to install wicd ?
Yes, sorry I did that backwareds
hehehe lucky i was awake
i'll do them reverse then
sudo apt-get install wicd ; sudo apt-get remove network-manager
its necessary to remove network manager for it to work then ?
Sorry, my mistake.
no worries, shit happens
no need to apologize even :)
but it is necessary to remove network manager ?
or should I install wicd and try it without removing first ?
Yes
sudo apt-get install wicd ; sudo apt-get remove network-manager
got it
Good.  Now try and connect again.
